facts.text: The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court which was allowed.

anchor.surface_text: Imam, J. The respondent Jagan Nath filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court which was allowed.

facts.text: The High Court ordered the respondent The Union of India and the appellant Sohan Lal to forthwith restore possession of house No. 35 situated in West Patel Nagar, Delhi to Jagan Nath.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court ordered the respondent The Union of India and the appellant Sohan Lal to forthwith restore possession of house No. 35 situated in West Patel Nagar, Delhi to Jagan Nath.

facts.text: Against this order of the High Court the appellant applied for and obtained special leave to appeal to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of the High Court the appellant applied for and obtained special leave to appeal to this Court.

facts.text: Jagan Nath is a displaced person and a refugee from Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath is a displaced person and a refugee from Pakistan.

facts.text: The Government of India had devised various schemes for the rehabilitation of refugees.

anchor.surface_text: The Government of India had devised various schemes for the rehabilitation of refugees.

facts.text: One of these was a scheme for sale of certain houses constructed by the Government of India for refugees in West Patel Nagar.

anchor.surface_text: One of these was a scheme for sale of certain houses companystructed by the Government of India for refugees in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: It was intended under the scheme to entertain applications from displaced persons who had already been allotted agricultural land in East Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: It was number intended under the scheme to entertain applications from displaced persons who had already been allotted agricultural land in East Punjab.

facts.text: Only those displaced persons, who were registered before the 15th of August, 1948, and were gainfully employed, were eligible for allotment of a house.

anchor.surface_text: According to the procedure prescribed in order to give effect to the scheme, only those displaced persons, who were registered before the 15th of August, 1948, and were gainfully employed, were eligible for allotment of a house.

facts.text: Jagan Nath had got himself registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath had got himself registered as a refugee on December 31, 1947.

facts.text: He had made his application in the prescribed form.

anchor.surface_text: He had made his application in the prescribed form.

facts.text: He had deposited the sum of Rs. 5,600 as the sale price after his prima facie eligibility had been accepted.

anchor.surface_text: He had deposited the sum of Rs. 5,600 as the sale price after his prima facie eligibility had been accepted.

facts.text: He had also deposited the ground rent for the plot on which the house had been built.

anchor.surface_text: He had also deposited the ground rent for the plot on which the house had been built, having been informed previously that it had been decided to allot him a two-roomed enclosed verandah box-type house in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: He was informed that the allotment of a particular house would be decided by drawing lots at site on February 15, 1952, at 3 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: He was informed that the allotment of a particular house would be decided by drawing lots at site on February 15, 1952, at 3 p.m.

facts.text: As the result of the drawing of lots, house No. 35, the property in dispute in this appeal, fell to his lot.

anchor.surface_text: As the result of the drawing of lots, house No. 35, the property in dispute in this appeal, fell to his lot.

facts.text: According to Jagan Nath, on May 10, 1952, the Accommodation Officer in his absence removed the members of his family along with his entire belongings to the house in dispute in a truck and he and his family thus entered into possession of the house in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: According to Jagan Nath, on May 10, 1952, the Accommodation Officer in his absence removed the members of his family along with his entire belongings to the house in dispute in a truck and he and his family thus entered into possession of the house in dispute.

facts.text: Jagan Nath was evicted from the house in dispute on September 27, 1952, by virtue of a warrant of eviction dated September 11, 1952, purporting to have been issued under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath, however, was evicted from the house in dispute on September 27, 1952, by virtue of a warrant of eviction dated September 11, 1952, purporting to have been issued under s. 25 of Ordinance III of 1952.

facts.text: After his eviction, possession of the house in dispute was given to the appellant on October 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: After his eviction, possession of the house in dispute was given to the appellant on October 3, 1952.

facts.text: The appellant, who is also a displaced person, had applied on February 27, 1952, for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, who is also a displaced person, had applied on February 27, 1952, for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar.

facts.text: He had made the deposit of Rs. 5,600 as sale price and had apparently complied with all the necessary conditions for allotment of a house to him.

anchor.surface_text: He had made the deposit of Rs. 5,600 as sale price and had apparently complied with all the necessary conditions for allotment of a house to him and the house in dispute was allotted to him on July 31, 1952.

facts.text: The house in dispute was allotted to him on July 31, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: the house in dispute was allotted to him on July 31, 1952.

facts.text: The appellant has been in possession of the disputed house since October 3, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has been in possession of the disputed house since October 3, 1952.

facts.text: Jagan Nath had been allotted agricultural land in the District of Hissar.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Union of India is that under the scheme Jagan Nath was number eligible for allotment of a house in West Patel Nagar, as it was subsequently discovered that he had been allotted, previous to his application, agricultural land in the District of Hissar.

facts.text: The Union of India refused to allot to him the tenement No. 35, West Patel Nagar.

anchor.surface_text: Being satisfied that Jagan Nath was number eligible for allotment, the Union of India refused to allot to him the tenement No. 35, West Patel Nagar and allotment of that house was made to the appellant who was found to be eligible in every way.

facts.text: A letter of allotment was actually issued to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had complied with all the conditions imposed by the Union of India and a letter of allotment was actually issued to him

facts.text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act.

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in contravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act.

facts.text: There is no evidence and no finding of the High Court that the appellant was in collusion with the Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence and numberfinding of the High Court that the appellant was in companylusion with the Union of India or that he had knowledge that the eviction of Jagan Nath was illegal.

facts.text: The High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did.

facts.text: The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

issues.text: Whether the High Court erred in issuing an order in the nature of a writ of mandamus under Art. 226 due to serious disputes on questions of fact and title to the property

anchor.surface_text: The appellants main contention has been that, having regard to the circumstances of the case, the High Court erred in making the order it did which presumably purported to be in the nature of a writ of mandamus. There was a serious dispute on questions of fact between the parties and also whether Jagan Nath had acquired in law any title to the property in dispute.

issues.text: Whether proceedings by way of writ under Art. 226 are appropriate where decision would amount to decree declaring title and ordering restoration of possession

anchor.surface_text: Proceedings by way of a writ were not appropriate in a case where the decision of the Court would amount to a decree declaring Jagan Naths title and ordering restoration of possession. The proper remedy open to Jagan Nath was to get his title declared in the ordinary way in a Civil Court.

issues.text: Whether a writ of mandamus or order in the nature of mandamus could be made against the appellant, a private individual

anchor.surface_text: It was further contended on behalf of the appellant that a writ of mandamus or an order in the nature of mandamus could not be made against the appellant, a private individual.

issues.text: Whether Jagan Nath was illegally evicted without complying with s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: S. 3 of the Public Premises  Eviction  Act, 1950  Act No. XXVII of 1950 , required a notice to be served upon him directing him to vacate the premises within 15 days from the date of the service of the notice upon him before he could be evicted. This was not done

issues.text: What rights were acquired by Jagan Nath in the property as against the Union of India up to the stage when informed that property would not be allotted

anchor.surface_text: As between Jagan Nath and the Union of India it will be necessary to decide what rights were acquired by the former in the property up to the stage when the latter informed Jagan Nath that the property in question could not be allotted to him.

issues.text: Whether Jagan Nath was allowed to enter into possession because allotted or under misapprehension as Union of India misled by application contents

anchor.surface_text: Another question for decision will be whether Jagan Nath was allowed to enter into possession of the property because it was allotted to him or under a misapprehension as the Union of India was misled by the contents of his application.

issues.text: Did the appellant acquire a legal right to hold the property as against Jagan Nath

anchor.surface_text: Did the appellant thereby acquire a legal right to hold the property as against Jagan Nath ? In our opinion, all these questions should be decided in a properly constituted suit in a Civil Court rather than in proceedings under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: We do number propose to enquire into the merits of the rival claims of title to the property in dispute set up by the appellant and Jagan Nath. If we were to do so, we would be entering into a field of investigation which is more appropriate for a Civil Court in a properly companystituted suit to do rather than for a Court exercising the prerogative of issuing writs.

anchor.surface_text: We do number propose to enquire into the merits of the rival claims of title to the property in dispute set up by the appellant and Jagan Nath. If we were to do so, we would be entering into a field of investigation which is more appropriate for a Civil Court in a properly companystituted suit to do rather than for a Court exercising the prerogative of issuing writs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disputed questions of fact and law on title require full trial in civil court; writ court not substitute for suit declaring title and possession.

holdings.text: There are questions of fact and law which are in dispute requiring determination before the respective claims of the parties to this appeal can be decided. Before the property in dispute can be restored to Jagan Nath it will be necessary to declare that he had title in that property and was entitled to recover possession of it. This would in effect amount to passing a decree in his favour.

anchor.surface_text: There are questions of fact and law which are in dispute requiring determination before the respective claims of the parties to this appeal can be decided. Before the property in dispute can be restored to Jagan Nath it will be necessary to declare that he had title in that property and was entitled to recover possession of it. This would in effect amount to passing a decree in his favour.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Writ relief would equate to civil decree on title and possession; inappropriate under Art.226 where alternative civil remedy exists.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandamus enforces public duties attached to office; not against private persons (citing Halsbury).

holdings.text: If it had been proved that the Union of India and the appellant had companyluded, and the transaction between them was merely companyourable, entered into with a view to deprive Jagan Nath of his rights, jurisdiction to issue a writ to or make an order in the nature of mandamus against the appellant might be said to exist in a Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exception to no-mandamus rule if collusion with authority renders transaction colourable.

holdings.text: In our opinion, the High Court erred in allowing the application of Jagan Nath filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution and making the order it did. The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of inappropriate jurisdiction for title disputes and no basis for mandamus against private appellant without collusion.

precedents.cited_proposition: Court cited for proposition that mandamus will not lie against de facto possessor unless merely colourable; must use quo warranto or similar; applied analogously to private possession of property
precedents.cited_holding: it is an inflexible rule of law that where a person has been de facto elected to a corporate office, and has accepted and acted in the office, the validity of the election and the title to the office can only be tried by proceeding on a quo warranto information. A mandamus will not lie unless the election can be shown to be merely colourable.

anchor.surface_text: We do number propose to enquire into the merits of the rival claims of title to the property in dispute set up by the appellant and Jagan Nath. If we were to do so, we would be entering into a field of investigation which is more appropriate for a Civil Court in a properly companystituted suit to do rather than for a Court exercising the prerogative of issuing writs.

anchor.surface_text: There are questions of fact and law which are in dispute requiring determination before the respective claims of the parties to this appeal can be decided. Before the property in dispute can be restored to Jagan Nath it will be necessary to declare that he had title in that property and was entitled to recover possession of it. This would in effect amount to passing a decree in his favour.
The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: The eviction of Jagan Nath was in companytravention of the express provisions of s. 3 of the Public Premises Eviction Act. His eviction, therefore, was illegal. He was entitled to be evicted in due companyrse of law and a writ of mandamus companyld issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus companyld be made against the Union of India to restore possession of the property to Jagan Nath from which he had been evicted the property was still in the possession of the Union of India.

The property in dispute, however, is in possession of the appellant.

There is numberevidence and numberfinding of the High Court that the appellant was in companylusion with the Union of India or that he had knowledge that the eviction of Jagan Nath was illegal. anchor.surface_text: Normally, a writ of mandamus does number issue to or an order in the nature of mandamus is number made against a private individual. Such an order is made against a person directing him to do some particular thing, specified in the order, which appertains to his office and is in the nature of a public duty  Halsburys Laws of England Vol. 11, Lord Simonds Edition, p. 84 .
The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: If it had been proved that the Union of India and the appellant had companyluded, and the transaction between them was merely companyourable, entered into with a view to deprive Jagan Nath of his rights, jurisdiction to issue a writ to or make an order in the nature of mandamus against the appellant might be said to exist in a Court.
The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside.
